style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;">Note 1&#160;- Basis of Presentation and Related Information</span><span We refer to our common shares, par value </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20519608e555-wk-Fact-F0CEE120A5CD51BCB13CBB2B340720FF" name="us-gaap:CommonStockParOrStatedValuePerShare" contextRef="FI2020Q3" unitRef="usdPerShare" decimals="INF" scale="0" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">0.10</ix:nonFraction></span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> per share, as &#8220;common stock.&#8221;  References to the "FASB&#8221; refer to the Financial Accounting Standards Board.  References to &#8220;GAAP&#8221; refer to United States (&#8220;U.S.&#8221;) generally accepted accounting principles.&#160;&#160;References to &#8220;ASU&#8221; refer to the codification of GAAP in the Accounting Standards Updates issued by the FASB.&#160;&#160;References to "ASC" refer to the codification of GAAP in the Accounting Standards Codification issued by the FASB.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">We incorporated as Helen of Troy Corporation in Texas in 1968 and were reorganized as Helen of Troy Limited in Bermuda in 1994.&#160;&#160;We are a global designer, developer, importer, marketer, and distributor of an expanding portfolio of brand-name consumer products.&#160;&#160;We have </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span><ix:nonFraction id="d20519608e564-wk-Fact-95C08B549C2D58A68DE410B89387761D" name="us-gaap:NumberOfReportableSegments" contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD" unitRef="Segment" decimals="INF" scale="0" format="ixt-sec:numwordsen">three</ix:nonFraction></span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> segments: Housewares, Health &amp; Home, and Beauty.&#160;&#160;Our Housewares segment provides a broad range of innovative consumer products for the home.&#160;&#160;Product offerings include food preparation tools and storage containers; cleaning, bath and garden tools and accessories; infant and toddler care products; and insulated beverage, food containers and coolers.&#160;&#160;The Health &amp; Home segment focuses on health care devices such as thermometers, humidifiers, blood pressure monitors, and heating pads; water filtration systems; and small home appliances such as portable heaters, fans, air purifiers, and insect control devices.&#160;&#160;Our Beauty segment products include electric hair care, beauty care and wellness appliances; grooming tools and accessories; and liquid-, solid- and powder-based personal care and grooming products.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">In December 2017, we completed the divestiture of the Nutritional Supplements segment through the sale of Healthy Directions LLC and its subsidiaries to Direct Digital, LLC.&#160;&#160;The results of the Nutritional Supplements operations have been reported as discontinued operations for all periods presented in the consolidated financial statements.&#160;&#160;For more information, see </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Note 5</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> to these condensed consolidated financial statements.&#160;&#160;All other notes present results from continuing operations.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Our business is seasonal due to different calendar events, holidays and seasonal weather patterns. Historically, our highest sales volume and operating income occur in our third fiscal quarter ending November 30</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:8pt;"><sup style="vertical-align:top;line-height:120%;font-size:5pt">th</sup></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">.&#160;&#160;We purchase our products from unaffiliated manufacturers, most of which are located in China, Mexico and the United States.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><ix:nonNumeric contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD" name="us-gaap:BasisOfAccountingPolicyPolicyTextBlock" id="TextSelection-FDD6FB96003B33196372C7AA6C663EE5-0-wk-Fact-75BA74703DDDA813B3AFC7ADFF87A177" escape="true"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Our condensed consolidated financial statements&#160;are prepared in U.S. Dollars.&#160;&#160;All intercompany accounts and transactions are eliminated in consolidation.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">The preparation of financial statements in accordance with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in our condensed consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes.  Actual results may differ materially from those estimates.</span></div></ix:nonNumeric></ix:nonNumeric><div><br/></div><div style="text-align:center;"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:10pt;">7</span></div></div><hr style="page-break-after:always"></hr><div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><a style="font-family:Arial;font-size:10pt;" href="#s566B28AC7F4D55EC973F7457E5A47EAB"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:10pt;">Table of Contents</span></a></div></div><div><br/></div><ix:continuation id="TextSelection-2E6F79F3556752D2BEA5770EFCFC84D4-1" continuedAt="TextSelection-2E6F79F3556752D2BEA5770EFCFC84D4-2"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div></ix:continuation><ix:nonNumeric contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD" name="us-gaap:PriorPeriodReclassificationAdjustmentDescription" id="TextSelection-6CBE3B54D377AB769A50C7AA9B8FB059-0-wk-Fact-BF61A8DAE98E8E2879C2C7B34885FF55" escape="true"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><ix:continuation id="TextSelection-2E6F79F3556752D2BEA5770EFCFC84D4-2">We have reclassified, combined or separately disclosed certain amounts in the prior years&#8217; condensed consolidated financial statements and accompanying footnotes to conform with the current period&#8217;s presentation.</ix:continuation> </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div></ix:nonNumeric><div><a id="sCDE11E601EFB5BDA83387BD93E7641FC"></a></div><ix:nonNumeric contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD" name="us-gaap:NewAccountingPronouncementsAndChangesInAccountingPrinciplesTextBlock" id="TextSelection-9A7B43BADE1F55F0806D79E9EA1EEE08-0-wk-Fact-CB7940A9556A5E28AA31024EE0001089" continuedAt="TextSelection-9A7B43BADE1F55F0806D79E9EA1EEE08-1" escape="true"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;">Note 2&#160;- New Accounting Pronouncements</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;"> </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">&#160;</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:left;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Except for the changes discussed below, there have been no changes in the information provided in our Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended February 28, 2019.&#160;&#160;</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><ix:nonNumeric contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD" name="us-gaap:NewAccountingPronouncementsPolicyPolicyTextBlock" id="TextSelection-67BB67EEAA775555BF84B676212988AA-0-wk-Fact-191E2FFBFDF350F0B7912C421E25649F" continuedAt="TextSelection-67BB67EEAA775555BF84B676212988AA-1" escape="true"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;">Adopted in Fiscal 2020</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU&#160;2016-02,&#160;</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-style:italic;">Leases (Topic 842)</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">.&#160; The new guidance requires the recognition of lease liabilities, representing future minimum lease payments, on a discounted basis, and corresponding&#160;right-of-use&#160;assets on a balance sheet for most leases, along with requirements for enhanced disclosures to give financial statement users the ability to assess the amount, timing and uncertainty of cash flows arising from leasing arrangements.  In July 2018, the FASB issued guidance  which permits application of the new guidance at the beginning of the year of adoption, recognizing a cumulative-effect adjustment to the opening balance of retained earnings in the period of adoption, in addition to the method of applying the new guidance retrospectively to each prior reporting period presented.  We adopted the standard in the first quarter of fiscal 2020 using the transition method introduced by ASU 2018-11, which does not require revisions to comparative periods.  We elected to implement the transition package of practical expedients permitted within the new standard, which included (i) not reassessing whether expired or existing contracts contain leases, (ii) not reassessing lease classification, and (iii) not revaluing initial direct costs for existing leases.  Adoption of the new standard resulted in the recording of initial lease assets and lease liabilities of approximately </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20509630e556-wk-Fact-EF7CA07F7FE2511DB49B656C5C882027" name="us-gaap:OperatingLeaseRightOfUseAsset" contextRef="I2019Q1March1_us-gaap_AdjustmentsForNewAccountingPronouncementsAxis_us-gaap_AccountingStandardsUpdate201602Member" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">37.1</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> and </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20509630e560-wk-Fact-A8BF1735DED35EF0BC69224E22CBFF45" name="us-gaap:OperatingLeaseLiability" contextRef="I2019Q1March1_us-gaap_AdjustmentsForNewAccountingPronouncementsAxis_us-gaap_AccountingStandardsUpdate201602Member" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">47.2</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">, respectively, as of March 1, 2019.  The difference between the lease assets and lease liabilities primarily relates to deferred rent and unamortized lease incentives recorded in accordance with the previous lease guidance.  The new standard did not materially impact our condensed consolidated statements of income or cash flows (see </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Note 4</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">).</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div></ix:nonNumeric></ix:nonNumeric><ix:continuation id="TextSelection-67BB67EEAA775555BF84B676212988AA-1"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><ix:continuation id="TextSelection-9A7B43BADE1F55F0806D79E9EA1EEE08-1" continuedAt="TextSelection-9A7B43BADE1F55F0806D79E9EA1EEE08-2"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">In August 2017, the FASB issued ASU 2017-12,&#160;</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-style:italic;">Derivatives and Hedging - Targeted Improvements to Accounting for Hedging Activities (Topic 815)</span></ix:continuation><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><ix:continuation id="TextSelection-9A7B43BADE1F55F0806D79E9EA1EEE08-2">, which amends and simplifies hedge accounting with the intent of better aligning financial reporting for hedging relationships with an entity's risk management activities.  In April 2019, the FASB issued ASU 2019-04, which provides clarifications and minor improvements related to Topic 815.  Adoption of this guidance in the first quarter of fiscal 2020 did not have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements.</ix:continuation>  </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div></ix:continuation><div><a id="s319D41424B3D52CAAE1468FFF702E746"></a></div><ix:nonNumeric contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD" name="us-gaap:RevenueFromContractWithCustomerTextBlock" id="TextSelection-D67C97AAB2525ACFBF108B806207B54F-0-wk-Fact-91E1055E526156D3817C758C72F5CC48" continuedAt="TextSelection-D67C97AAB2525ACFBF108B806207B54F-1" escape="true"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;">Note 3&#160;- Revenue Recognition</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;"> </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">We adopted the provisions of ASU 2014-9 in the first quarter of fiscal 2019, and we elected to adopt the standard using the retrospective method.  The core principle of the guidance is that a company should recognize revenue to depict the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.&#160;</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Our revenue is primarily generated from the sale of non-customized consumer products to customers.  Revenue is recognized when control of, and title to, the product sold transfers to the customer.  Therefore, the timing and amount of revenue recognized was not materially impacted by the new guidance.  We have thus concluded that the adoption of the guidance did not have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements.  The provisions of the new guidance did however impact the classification of certain consideration paid to our customers.  We therefore reclassified an immaterial </span></div></ix:nonNumeric><div><br/></div><div style="text-align:center;"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:10pt;">8</span></div></div><hr style="page-break-after:always"></hr><div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><a style="font-family:Arial;font-size:10pt;" href="#s566B28AC7F4D55EC973F7457E5A47EAB"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:10pt;">Table of Contents</span></a></div></div><div><br/></div><ix:continuation id="TextSelection-D67C97AAB2525ACFBF108B806207B54F-1" continuedAt="TextSelection-D67C97AAB2525ACFBF108B806207B54F-2"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">amount of such payments from SG&amp;A to a reduction of net sales revenue for all periods presented.  Also, in accordance with the guidance, we reclassified an immaterial amount of estimated sales returns from a reduction of receivables to accrued expenses and other current liabilities for all periods presented.&#160;&#160;We elected to adopt the guidance using the full retrospective method.&#160;</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">We measure revenue as the amount of consideration for which we expect to be entitled, in exchange for transferring goods.&#160;&#160;Certain customers may receive cash incentives such as customer discounts (including volume or trade discounts), advertising discounts and other customer-related programs which are accounted for as variable consideration.&#160;&#160;In some cases, we apply judgment, such as contractual rates and historical payment trends, when estimating variable consideration.&#160;&#160;In accordance with the guidance, most variable consideration is classified as a reduction to net sales.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div></ix:continuation><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><ix:continuation id="TextSelection-D67C97AAB2525ACFBF108B806207B54F-2">Sales taxes and other similar taxes are excluded from revenue.&#160;&#160;We elected to account for shipping and handling activities as a fulfillment cost as permitted by the guidance.&#160;&#160;We do not have unsatisfied performance obligations since our performance obligations are satisfied at a single point in time.</ix:continuation>  </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-left:4px;text-align:left;padding-left:48px;font-size:9pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:9pt;"><br/></span></div><div><a id="s8A5AA0A8BC065210B5A74BDCFEF1376A"></a></div><ix:nonNumeric contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD" name="us-gaap:LesseeOperatingLeasesTextBlock" id="TextSelection-121000867D915D618917360DF3F9DFA9-0-wk-Fact-47160EBC49D35F119DAE1474277C5139" continuedAt="TextSelection-121000867D915D618917360DF3F9DFA9-1" escape="true"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;">Note 4&#160;- Leases</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;"> </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-bottom:6px;padding-top:6px;text-align:left;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Adoption of the new lease standard resulted in the recording of lease assets and lease liabilities of approximately </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20524607e536-wk-Fact-EF7CA07F7FE2511DB49B656C5C882027" name="us-gaap:OperatingLeaseRightOfUseAsset" contextRef="I2019Q1March1_us-gaap_AdjustmentsForNewAccountingPronouncementsAxis_us-gaap_AccountingStandardsUpdate201602Member" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">37.1</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> and </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20524607e540-wk-Fact-A8BF1735DED35EF0BC69224E22CBFF45" name="us-gaap:OperatingLeaseLiability" contextRef="I2019Q1March1_us-gaap_AdjustmentsForNewAccountingPronouncementsAxis_us-gaap_AccountingStandardsUpdate201602Member" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">47.2</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">, respectively, as of March 1, 2019.  The difference between the lease assets and lease liabilities primarily relates to unamortized lease incentives and deferred rent recorded in accordance with the previous lease guidance.  The new standard did not materially impact our consolidated statements of income or cash flows. </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-bottom:6px;padding-top:6px;text-align:left;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">The Company primarily has leases for office space, which are classified as operating leases.  Operating leases are included in operating lease assets, accrued expenses and other current liabilities, and lease liabilities, non-current in our consolidated balance sheets.  Operating lease assets and operating lease liabilities are recognized based on the present value of the future lease payments over the lease term at  commencement date.  As most of our lease contracts do not provide an explicit interest rate, we use an estimated secured incremental borrowing rate based on the information available at commencement date in determining the present value of lease payments. </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-bottom:6px;padding-top:6px;text-align:left;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">We include options to extend or terminate the lease in the lease term for accounting considerations, when it is reasonably certain that we will exercise that option.  Our leases have remaining lease terms of less than one to </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span><ix:nonNumeric id="d20524607e550-wk-Fact-258E0C3588B55D709944C154916CDB34" name="hele:LesseeOperatingLeaseRemainingLeaseTerm" contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD_srt_RangeAxis_srt_MaximumMember" format="ixt-sec:duryear">13</ix:nonNumeric></span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> years.&#160; Lease expense for lease payments is recognized on a straight-line basis over the lease term in a manner similar to previous accounting guidance.  We do not recognize leases with an initial term of twelve months or less on the balance sheet and instead recognize the related lease payments as expense in the condensed consolidated statements of income on a straight-line basis over the lease term.  We account for lease and non-lease components as a single lease component for all asset classes.  Our lease agreements do not contain any material residual value guarantees or material restrictive covenants.  Under the new guidance, operating lease expense recognized in the condensed consolidated statements of income during the </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">three</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> and </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">nine</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> month periods ended </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">November 30, 2019</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> was </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20524607e566-wk-Fact-BBC678ADE63A592388480418BB56149D" name="us-gaap:OperatingLeaseExpense" contextRef="FD2020Q3QTD" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">1.5</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">and</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20524607e575-wk-Fact-A637EBC169A35FEEA0298F40999C6CD4" name="us-gaap:OperatingLeaseExpense" contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">4.8</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">, respectively.&#160; Short-term lease expense is excluded from this amount and is not material.&#160; The non-cash component of lease expense is included as an adjustment to reconcile income from continuing operations to net cash provided by operating activities in the condensed consolidated statements of cash flows. </span></div></ix:nonNumeric><div><br/></div><div style="text-align:center;"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:10pt;">9</span></div></div><hr style="page-break-after:always"></hr><div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div Contents</span></a></div></div><div><br/></div><ix:continuation id="TextSelection-121000867D915D618917360DF3F9DFA9-1" continuedAt="TextSelection-121000867D915D618917360DF3F9DFA9-2"><ix:nonNumeric contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD" name="us-gaap:LeaseCostTableTextBlock" id="TextSelection-D17DC35C45EE540BB71A357072E12639-0-wk-Fact-FCABF09FAAB55B3596A92C2488D9439A" escape="true"><div style="line-height:120%;padding-bottom:6px;padding-top:6px;text-align:left;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">A summary of supplemental lease information is as follows:  </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><div style="padding-left:0px;text-indent:0px;line-height:normal;padding-top:10px;"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;">Note 9&#160;- Repurchase of Helen of Troy Common Stock</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;"> </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:12pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">In May 2019, we announced that our Board of Directors had authorized the repurchase of up to </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20526868e538-wk-Fact-B84809214DF05445A7CB16A8335D8CC5" name="us-gaap:StockRepurchaseProgramAuthorizedAmount1" common stock.</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:12pt;">&#160; </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">The authorization is effective May 8, 2019 for a period of </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span><ix:nonNumeric id="d20526868e546-wk-Fact-462B7015B2015FA5843EBEA56B19D333" name="us-gaap:StockRepurchaseProgramPeriodInForce1" contextRef="D2019Q2May8" format="ixt-sec:durwordsen">three years</ix:nonNumeric></span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> and replaced Helen of Troy's previous repurchase authorization, of which approximately </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20526868e550-wk-Fact-EB892BDC845E50CBA6A50512C4706D94" name="hele:StockRepurchasePriorProgramRemainingAuthorizedRepurchaseAmount" contextRef="I2019Q2May8" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">107.4</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> remained.  These repurchases may include open market purchases, privately negotiated transactions, block trades, accelerated stock repurchase transactions, or any combination of such methods.  The number of shares purchased and the timing of the purchases will depend on a number of factors, including share price, trading volume and general market conditions, working capital requirements, general business conditions, financial conditions, any applicable contractual limitations, and other factors, including alternative investment opportunities.&#160;&#160;As of </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">November 30, 2019</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">, our repurchase authorization allowed for the purchase of </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20526868e559-wk-Fact-F466FEE5DAFA5306BE1C03C0D106B973" name="us-gaap:StockRepurchaseProgramRemainingAuthorizedRepurchaseAmount1" contextRef="FI2020Q3" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">393.0</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> of common stock.&#160;</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Our current equity-based compensation plans include provisions that allow for the &#8220;net exercise&#8221; of share-settled awards by all plan participants.&#160;&#160;In a net exercise, any required payroll taxes, federal withholding taxes and exercise price of the shares due from the equity holder can be paid for by having the equity holder tender back to the Company a number of shares at fair value equal to the amounts due.&#160;&#160;Net exercises are treated as purchases and retirements of shares. </span></div><div escape="true"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;">Note 10&#160;- Restructuring Plan</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;"> </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">In October 2017, we announced that we had approved a restructuring plan (referred to as &#8220;Project Refuel&#8221;).  Project Refuel includes a reduction-in-force and the elimination of certain contracts and operating expenses.&#160;&#160;We are targeting total annualized profit improvements of approximately </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20534008e538-wk-Fact-C0994C13C69F54A88B7B668B4885E227" name="hele:TargetedAnnualizedProfitImprovement" contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD_srt_RangeAxis_srt_MinimumMember_us-gaap_RestructuringPlanAxis_hele_ProjectRefuelMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">8.0</ix:nonFraction></span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> to </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20534008e542-wk-Fact-B1C9DC3F49B65F5CB8175E74A064F65D" name="hele:TargetedAnnualizedProfitImprovement" contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD_srt_RangeAxis_srt_MaximumMember_us-gaap_RestructuringPlanAxis_hele_ProjectRefuelMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">10.0</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> over the duration of the plan.&#160;&#160;We estimate the plan will be completed during fiscal 2020, and expect to incur total restructuring charges of approximately </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20534008e546-wk-Fact-7ACE1A3DCFE8598F84562B1A453D091E" name="us-gaap:RestructuringCharges" contextRef="FD2020Q4YTD_us-gaap_RestructuringPlanAxis_hele_ProjectRefuelMember_us-gaap_StatementScenarioAxis_us-gaap_ScenarioForecastMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">7.0</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> over the duration of the plan.  Restructuring provisions are determined based on estimates prepared at the time the restructuring actions are approved by management and are revised periodically. </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">For the three month period ended November 30, 2019, we incurred an insignificant amount of pre-tax restructuring charges. Since implementing Project Refuel, we have incurred </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20534008e559-wk-Fact-AB5C20F2B9785087A97CB749A123B059" name="us-gaap:RestructuringAndRelatedCostCostIncurredToDate1" contextRef="FI2020Q3_us-gaap_RestructuringPlanAxis_hele_ProjectRefuelMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">6.5</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> of pre-tax restructuring costs as of </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">November 30, 2019</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">.&#160; During the </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">three and nine</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> month periods ended </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">November 30, 2019</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">, we made total cash restructuring payments of </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20534008e576-wk-Fact-1CEDDC9E6FCEE7CAC763FB5A3E8E97F1" name="us-gaap:PaymentsForRestructuring" contextRef="FD2020Q3QTD" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">0.3</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> and </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20534008e580-wk-Fact-119EA746FFB055BB8187A714C2604E6F" name="us-gaap:PaymentsForRestructuring" contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">1.8</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">, respectively.  Since implementing Project Refuel, we have made total cash restructuring payments of </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20534008e584-wk-Fact-C1DE35E495395B1B8763F897CFBE434D" name="hele:PaymentsForRestructuringToDate" contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD_us-gaap_RestructuringPlanAxis_hele_ProjectRefuelMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">6.0</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">. style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">All of our debt is unconditionally guaranteed, on a joint and several basis, by the Company and certain of its subsidiaries.&#160;&#160;Our debt agreements require the maintenance of certain financial covenants, including a maximum leverage ratio and a minimum interest coverage ratio (as each of these terms is defined in the agreements).&#160;&#160;Our debt agreements also contain other customary covenants.&#160;&#160;We were in compliance with the terms of these agreements as of </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">November 30, name="us-gaap:FairValueDisclosuresTextBlock" id="TextSelection-D529C384FBF25ED89AA10C67A9B459A1-0-wk-Fact-ACD7FEDB9821563081CAE2ADDF4C8FDC" continuedAt="TextSelection-D529C384FBF25ED89AA10C67A9B459A1-1" escape="true"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;">Note 13 - Fair Value</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;">&#160;</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">We classify our various assets and liabilities recorded or reported at fair value under a hierarchy prescribed by GAAP that prioritizes inputs to fair value measurement techniques into three broad levels:</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-family:Times New Roman; font-size:10pt;"><tr><td style="width:96px;"></td><td></td></tr><tr><td style="vertical-align:top"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;padding-left:24px;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Level 1:</span></div></td><td style="vertical-align:top;"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Observable inputs such as quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets;</span></div></td></tr></table><div style="line-height:120%;padding-left:48px;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-family:Times New Roman; font-size:10pt;"><tr><td style="width:96px;"></td><td></td></tr><tr><td style="vertical-align:top"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;padding-left:24px;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Level 2:</span></div></td><td style="vertical-align:top;"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Observable inputs other than quoted prices that are directly or indirectly observable for the asset or liability, including quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities in active markets; quoted prices for similar or identical assets or liabilities in markets that are not active; and model-derived valuations whose inputs are observable or whose significant value drivers are observable; and</span></div></td></tr></table><div style="line-height:120%;padding-left:96px;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-family:Times New Roman; font-size:10pt;"><tr><td style="width:96px;"></td><td></td></tr><tr><td style="vertical-align:top"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;padding-left:24px;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Level 3:</span></div></td><td style="vertical-align:top;"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Unobservable inputs that reflect the reporting entity&#8217;s own assumptions.</span></div></td></tr></table><div style="line-height:120%;padding-left:48px;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Assets and liabilities subject to classification are classified upon acquisition.&#160;&#160;When circumstances dictate the transfer of an asset or liability to a different level, our policy is to recognize the transfer at the beginning of the reporting period in which the event resulting in the transfer occurred.  </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><ix:nonNumeric contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD" style="width:24px;"></td><td></td></tr><tr><td style="vertical-align:top"><ix:continuation id="TextSelection-CB97E7EFC1DF5BC9BD6E304DB3AD1FED-2" continuedAt="TextSelection-CB97E7EFC1DF5BC9BD6E304DB3AD1FED-3"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:9pt;padding-left:0px;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:9pt;">(1)</span></div></ix:continuation></td><td style="vertical-align:top;"><ix:continuation id="TextSelection-CB97E7EFC1DF5BC9BD6E304DB3AD1FED-3"><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:left;font-size:9pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:9pt;">Our financial assets and liabilities are classified as Level 2 because their valuation is dependent on observable inputs and other quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities, or model-derived valuations whose significant value drivers are observable.</span></div></ix:continuation></td></tr></table><div style="line-height:120%;padding-left:4px;text-align:left;padding-left:24px;font-size:9pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:9pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">The carrying amounts of cash and cash equivalents, receivables and accounts payable approximate fair value because of the short maturity of these items.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">We use derivatives for hedging purposes and our derivatives are primarily interest rate swaps, foreign currency contracts and cross-currency debt swaps.&#160;&#160;See Notes 12 and </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">14</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> to these condensed consolidated financial statements for more information on our hedging activities.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">We classify our floating rate debt as a Level 2 item because the estimation of the fair market value requires the use of a discount rate based upon current market rates of interest for obligations with comparable remaining terms.&#160;&#160;Such comparable rates are considered significant other observable market inputs.&#160;&#160;The book value of the floating rate debt approximates its fair value as of the reporting date.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Our other non-financial assets include goodwill and other intangible assets, which we classify as Level 3 items.&#160;&#160;These assets are measured at fair value on a non-recurring basis as part of our impairment testing.&#160;&#160;</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Note 7</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> to these condensed consolidated financial statements contains additional information related to intangible asset impairments.</span></div></ix:continuation><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div><a id="s3A60F1ECD2205797A78C78AF40E43177"></a></div><ix:nonNumeric contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD" name="us-gaap:FinancialInstrumentsDisclosureTextBlock" id="TextSelection-CC284A47CF6357B6A987C216FEC78C8A-0-wk-Fact-0BF090EFACAE5D8FBA387ED9352EDB30" continuedAt="TextSelection-CC284A47CF6357B6A987C216FEC78C8A-1" escape="true"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;">Note 14 - Financial Instruments and Risk Management</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;"> </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;">Foreign Currency Risk</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:11pt;"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">- Our functional currency is the U.S. Dollar.&#160;&#160;By operating internationally, we are subject to foreign currency risk from transactions denominated in currencies other than the U.S. Dollar (&#8220;foreign currencies&#8221;).&#160;&#160;Such transactions include sales, certain inventory purchases and operating expenses.&#160;&#160;As a result of such transactions, portions of our cash, trade accounts receivable and trade accounts payable are denominated in foreign currencies.&#160;&#160;During the </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">three and nine</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> month periods ended </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">November 30, 2019</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">, approximately </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span><ix:nonFraction id="d20545137e550-wk-Fact-CED73D0AD1C55F4C8A9EDD669FEC8A36" name="us-gaap:ConcentrationRiskPercentage1" unitRef="number" decimals="2" scale="-2" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">17</ix:nonFraction>%</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> and </span><span contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD_srt_StatementGeographicalAxis_hele_SegmentGeographicalGroupsOfCountriesNonUSDTransactionsMember_us-gaap_ConcentrationRiskByBenchmarkAxis_us-gaap_SalesRevenueNetMember_us-gaap_ConcentrationRiskByTypeAxis_us-gaap_GeographicConcentrationRiskMember" unitRef="number" decimals="2" scale="-2" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">14</ix:nonFraction>%</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">, respectively, of our net sales revenue was in foreign currencies.  For both the three and nine month periods ended November 30, 2018, approximately </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span><ix:nonFraction id="d20545137e559-wk-Fact-4814CC3D8C84541E83A4B94EAB1292F7" name="us-gaap:ConcentrationRiskPercentage1" contextRef="FD2019Q3YTD_srt_StatementGeographicalAxis_hele_SegmentGeographicalGroupsOfCountriesNonUSDTransactionsMember_us-gaap_ConcentrationRiskByBenchmarkAxis_us-gaap_SalesRevenueNetMember_us-gaap_ConcentrationRiskByTypeAxis_us-gaap_GeographicConcentrationRiskMember" unitRef="number" decimals="2" scale="-2" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">13</ix:nonFraction>%</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> of our net sales revenue was in foreign currencies.  These sales were primarily denominated in Euros, British Pounds, Canadian Dollars, and Mexican Pesos.  We make most of our inventory purchases from the Far East and primarily use the U.S. Dollar for such purchases.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">In our condensed consolidated statements of income, exchange gains and losses resulting from the remeasurement of foreign taxes receivable, taxes payable, deferred tax assets, and deferred tax liabilities are recognized in their respective income tax lines, and all other foreign exchange gains and losses are recognized in SG&amp;A.&#160; During the </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">three and nine</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">We hedge against certain foreign currency exchange rate-risk by using a series of forward contracts and zero-cost collars designated as cash flow hedges and mark-to-market derivatives to protect against the foreign currency exchange risk inherent in our forecasted transactions denominated in currencies other than the U.S. Dollar.  We do not enter into any forward exchange contracts or similar instruments for trading or other speculative purposes.  The effective portion of the changes in fair value of these instruments is reported in OCI and reclassified into SG&amp;A in the same period they are settled.  The ineffective portion, which is not material for any year presented, is immediately recognized in SG&amp;A.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;">Interest Rate Risk</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:11pt;"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">- Interest on our outstanding debt as of </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">November 30, 2019</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> is based on floating interest rates.&#160;&#160;If short-term interest rates increase, we will incur higher interest expense on any future outstanding balances of floating rate debt.  Floating interest rates are hedged with interest rate swaps to effectively fix interest rates on </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20545137e5920-wk-Fact-2A4EC522F5445F24957E971776B10DE5" contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD_us-gaap_DerivativeInstrumentRiskAxis_us-gaap_ForeignExchangeContractMember_us-gaap_DerivativeInstrumentsGainLossByHedgingRelationshipAxis_us-gaap_CashFlowHedgingMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" sign="-" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">1.5</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> associated with foreign currency contracts and interest rate swaps currently reported in accumulated other comprehensive income, to be reclassified into income over the next </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span><ix:nonNumeric id="d20545137e5924-wk-Fact-373A01FA710E509593FA6F768B53B060" name="us-gaap:DerivativeInstrumentsGainLossReclassificationFromAccumulatedOCIToIncomeEstimateOfTimeToTransfer1" contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD_us-gaap_DerivativeInstrumentRiskAxis_us-gaap_ForeignExchangeContractMember_us-gaap_DerivativeInstrumentsGainLossByHedgingRelationshipAxis_us-gaap_CashFlowHedgingMember" format="ixt-sec:durwordsen">twelve months</ix:nonNumeric></span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">.  The amount ultimately realized, however, will differ as exchange rates vary and the underlying contracts settle.&#160;</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Counterparty Credit Risk</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:11pt;"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">- Financial instruments, including foreign currency contracts and cross currency debt swaps, expose us to counterparty credit risk for non-performance.  We manage our exposure to counterparty credit risk by only dealing with counterparties who are substantial international financial institutions with significant experience using such derivative instruments.  Although our theoretical credit risk is the replacement cost at the then-estimated fair value of these instruments, we believe that the risk of incurring credit losses is remote.</span></div></ix:continuation><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div><br/></div><div style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div></td></tr></table></div></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div></ix:continuation><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">We compute segment operating income based on net sales revenue, less cost of goods sold, SG&amp;A, restructuring charges, and any asset impairment charges associated with the segment.  The SG&amp;A used to compute each segment&#8217;s operating income is directly associated with the segment, plus shared service and corporate overhead expenses that are allocable to the segment.&#160;&#160;We do not allocate non-operating income and expense, including interest or income taxes, to operating segments.</span></div></ix:continuation><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div><a id="s6DD0063458975B4F9D98F69257938DAC"></a></div><ix:nonNumeric contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD" name="us-gaap:IncomeTaxDisclosureTextBlock" id="TextSelection-C1F5A253075D5E908200DF422105CE17-0-wk-Fact-D66592CF043353E38B53714BB76CF94D" continuedAt="TextSelection-C1F5A253075D5E908200DF422105CE17-1" escape="true"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;">Note 17 - Income Taxes</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;"> </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-bottom:10px;text-align:left;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Due to our organization in Bermuda and the ownership structure of our foreign subsidiaries, many of which are not owned directly or indirectly by a U.S. parent company, an immaterial amount of our foreign income is subject to U.S. taxation on a permanent basis under current law.  Additionally, our intellectual property is largely owned by our foreign subsidiaries, resulting in proportionally higher earnings in jurisdictions with lower statutory tax rates, which decreases our overall effective tax rate.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-bottom:10px;text-align:left;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">For interim periods, our income tax expense and resulting effective tax rate are based upon an estimated annual effective tax rate adjusted for the effects of items required to be treated as discrete to the period, including changes in tax laws, changes in estimated exposures for uncertain tax positions and other items.  </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:left;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">For the </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">three</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> months ended </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">November 30, 2019</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">, income tax expense as a percentage of income before income tax was </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span><ix:nonFraction id="d20537457e552-wk-Fact-82965E40574054758E2ED85548EEE1BC" name="hele:IncomeTaxExpenseBenefitPercentageOfIncomeBeforeIncomeTaxes" contextRef="FD2020Q3QTD" unitRef="number" decimals="3" scale="-2" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">10.3</ix:nonFraction>%</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> compared to </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span><ix:nonFraction id="d20537457e556-wk-Fact-87EE11E3CCDF53BC9282D0F02BA99BAD" name="hele:IncomeTaxExpenseBenefitPercentageOfIncomeBeforeIncomeTaxes" contextRef="FD2019Q3QTD" unitRef="number" decimals="3" scale="-2" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">6.9</ix:nonFraction>%</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> for the same period last year.  The year-over-year increase in the effective tax rate is primarily due to shifts in the mix of taxable income in our various tax jurisdictions and increases in certain statutory tax rates.  </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:left;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:left;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">For the </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">nine</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> months ended </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">November 30, 2019</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">, income tax expense as a percentage of income before income tax was </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span><ix:nonFraction id="d20537457e573-wk-Fact-86888FD7C41F53CB944903DAE0709EFC" name="hele:IncomeTaxExpenseBenefitPercentageOfIncomeBeforeIncomeTaxes" contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD" unitRef="number" decimals="3" scale="-2" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">9.6</ix:nonFraction>%</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">, which included </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20537457e577-wk-Fact-A8FA660553DE5FCD92C6A98A262E57BA" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">1.0</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> of tax benefits from share-based compensation settlements, </span><span contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">1.7</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> of expense from the remeasurement of deferred taxes due to tax rate changes, and a </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20537457e586-wk-Fact-39B1EC7F9A3E5C0D961F9923E28C967C" name="hele:Unrecognizedtaxbenefitfromfavorableresolutionofuncertaintaxposition" contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">2.8</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> benefit from the resolution of an uncertain tax position.  Income tax expense as a percentage of income before income tax was </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span><ix:nonFraction id="d20537457e590-wk-Fact-D197E9266CB95D80AC1734B886E499E0" name="hele:IncomeTaxExpenseBenefitPercentageOfIncomeBeforeIncomeTaxes" contextRef="FD2019Q3YTD" unitRef="number" decimals="3" scale="-2" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">7.2</ix:nonFraction>%</span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> for the same period last year, which included </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20537457e594-wk-Fact-10B6E87AD14D584F8E1DD75762EBA497" name="hele:UnrecognizedTaxBenefitsDecreasesResultingFromRecognitionOfExcessTaxBenefitsFromShareBasedCompensation" contextRef="FD2019Q3YTD" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">0.7</ix:nonFraction></span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> million tax benefits from share-based compensation settlements and a </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d20537457e598-wk-Fact-E3CE0AC7B6C45BAAA7754FFBB06FF2FC" name="hele:Unrecognizedtaxbenefitfromfavorableresolutionofuncertaintaxposition" contextRef="FD2019Q3YTD" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">0.8</ix:nonFraction></span></span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> million benefit from the lapse of the statute of limitations related to an uncertain tax position.  The year-over-year increase in the effective tax rate is primarily due to shifts in the mix of taxable income in our various tax jurisdictions, increases in certain statutory tax rates and the comparative impact of discrete benefits recorded in the same period last year.   </span></div></ix:nonNumeric><div><br/></div><div style="text-align:center;"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:10pt;">22</span></div></div><hr style="page-break-after:always"></hr><div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><a style="font-family:Arial;font-size:10pt;" href="#s566B28AC7F4D55EC973F7457E5A47EAB"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:10pt;">Table of Contents</span></a></div></div><div><br/></div><ix:continuation id="TextSelection-C1F5A253075D5E908200DF422105CE17-1"><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:left;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:left;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">During fiscal 2017, we received an assessment from a state tax authority which adjusted taxable income applicable to the particular state resulting from interpretations of certain state income tax provisions applicable to our legal structure.&#160;&#160;We believe we have accurately reported our taxable income and are vigorously protesting the assessment through administrative processes with the state.&#160;&#160;We believe it is unlikely that the outcome of these matters will have a material adverse effect on our consolidated financial position, results of operations, or liquidity.  </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:left;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:left;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Our Macau subsidiary generates income from the sale of the goods that it has sourced and procured.  This subsidiary is responsible for the sourcing and procurement of a large portion of the products that we sell.  We currently have an indefinite tax holiday in Macau conditioned on the subsidiary meeting certain employment and investment thresholds.  The Macau Offshore Law and its supplementary regulations that grant tax incentives to approved offshore institutions will be abolished on January 1, 2021.  Existing approved offshore institutions such as ours can continue to operate under the offshore regime until the end of the calendar year 2020.  Beginning in calendar year 2021, we believe our Macau subsidiary will become subject to a statutory corporate income tax of approximately </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">12%</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">.  The ultimate impact of this change, if any, on our overall effective tax rate will depend on a variety of factors including our mix of income by jurisdiction, transfer pricing considerations and the specific tax regulations applicable to us when we are no longer under the Macau Offshore regime.  It is not practicable for us to determine the potential impact on our financial statements until the tax changes in Macau are fully established and our transfer pricing analysis is complete.  Because our Macau subsidiary is not directly or indirectly owned by a U.S. parent, there is no U.S. tax liability associated with the income generated in Macau.</span></div></ix:continuation><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:left;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div><a id="s1E1BA82B0EB65AAC865678B7030DDD7E"></a></div><ix:nonNumeric contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD" name="us-gaap:EarningsPerShareTextBlock" id="TextSelection-04D61891666659288C7A8923C4B78B18-0-wk-Fact-CC85D71DDCD15FF9884F1A615F7721AB" escape="true"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;">Note 18 - Earnings Per Share</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;font-weight:bold;"> </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">We compute basic earnings per share using the weighted average number of shares of common stock</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">outstanding during the period.&#160;&#160;We compute diluted earnings per share using the weighted average</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">number of shares of common stock outstanding plus the effect of dilutive securities.&#160;&#160;Dilutive securities at any given point in time may consist of outstanding options to purchase common stock and issued and contingently issuable unvested RSUs, PSUs, RSAs, PSAs and other stock based awards.&#160;&#160;See </span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;">Note 8</span><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"> to these condensed consolidated financial statements for more information regarding stock-based awards.&#160;&#160;Anti-dilutive securities are not included in the computation of diluted earnings per share under the treasury stock method.&#160;</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:11pt;"><span style="font-family:Arial;font-size:11pt;"><br/></span></div><ix:nonNumeric contextRef="FD2020Q3YTD"
